an5.134:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato rājā khattiyo muddhāvasitto yassaṃ yassaṃ disāyaṃ viharati, sakasmiṃyeva vijite viharati.
an5.134:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, with five factors an anointed aristocratic king lives in his own realm, no matter what region he lives in.

an5.134:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhāvasitto ubhato sujāto hoti mātito ca pitito ca, saṃsuddhagahaṇiko, yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena;
an5.134:2.2.eng: An anointed aristocratic king is well born on both his mother’s and father’s side, of pure descent, with irrefutable and impeccable genealogy back to the seventh paternal generation.

an5.134:2.3.eng: He is rich, affluent, and wealthy, with a full treasury and storehouses.

an5.134:2.4.pli: balavā kho pana hoti caturaṅginiyā senāya samannāgato assavāya ovādapaṭikarāya;
an5.134:2.4.eng: He is powerful, having an army of four divisions that is obedient and carries out instructions.

an5.134:2.5.pli: pariṇāyako kho panassa hoti paṇḍito viyatto medhāvī paṭibalo atītānāgatapaccuppanne atthe cintetuṃ;
an5.134:2.5.eng: He has a commander who is astute, competent, and intelligent, able to think issues through as they bear upon the past, future, and present.

an5.134:2.6.eng: These four things bring his glory to fruition.

an5.134:2.7.pli: So iminā yasapañcamena dhammena samannāgato yassaṃ yassaṃ disāyaṃ viharati, sakasmiṃyeva vijite viharati.
an5.134:2.7.eng: With these five qualities, including glory, an anointed aristocratic king lives in his own realm, no matter what direction he lives in.

an5.134:2.9.eng: Because that is how it is for victors.

an5.134:3.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu yassaṃ yassaṃ disāyaṃ viharati, vimuttacittova viharati.
an5.134:3.1.eng: In the same way, a mendicant with five qualities lives with mind freed, no matter what region they live in.

an5.134:3.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu—
an5.134:3.3.eng: It’s when mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an5.134:3.4.eng: This is like the anointed aristocratic king’s impeccable birth.

an5.134:3.5.pli: bahussuto hoti sutadharo sutasannicayo, ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ abhivadanti, tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā—
an5.134:3.5.eng: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

an5.134:3.6.pli: rājāva khattiyo muddhāvasitto aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāro;
an5.134:3.6.eng: This is like the anointed aristocratic king being rich, affluent, and wealthy, with full treasury and storehouses.

an5.134:3.7.pli: āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu—
an5.134:3.7.eng: They live with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

an5.134:3.8.eng: This is like the anointed aristocratic king having power.

an5.134:3.9.pli: paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā—
an5.134:3.9.eng: They’re wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

an5.134:3.10.eng: This is like the anointed aristocratic king having a commander.

an5.134:3.11.eng: These four qualities bring their freedom to fruition.

an5.134:3.12.pli: So iminā vimuttipañcamena dhammena samannāgato yassaṃ yassaṃ disāyaṃ viharati vimuttacittova viharati.
an5.134:3.12.eng: With these five qualities, including freedom, they live in their own realm, no matter what region they live in.

an5.134:3.14.eng: Because that is how it is for those whose mind is free.”

an5.135:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa jeṭṭho putto rajjaṃ pattheti.
an5.135:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, an anointed aristocratic king’s eldest son with five factors aspires to kingship.

an5.135:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa jeṭṭho putto ubhato sujāto hoti mātito ca pitito ca, saṃsuddhagahaṇiko, yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena;
an5.135:1.3.eng: It’s when an anointed aristocratic king’s eldest son is well born on both his mother’s and father’s side, of pure descent, with irrefutable and impeccable genealogy back to the seventh paternal generation.

an5.135:1.4.pli: abhirūpo hoti dassanīyo pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato;
an5.135:1.4.eng: He is attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty.

an5.135:1.5.eng: He is dear and beloved to his parents.

an5.135:1.6.eng: He is dear and beloved to the people of town and country.

an5.135:1.7.pli: yāni tāni raññaṃ khattiyānaṃ muddhāvasittānaṃ sippaṭṭhānāni hatthismiṃ vā assasmiṃ vā rathasmiṃ vā dhanusmiṃ vā tharusmiṃ vā tattha sikkhito hoti anavayo.
an5.135:1.7.eng: He is trained and skilled in the arts of anointed aristocratic kings, such as elephant riding, horse riding, driving a chariot, archery, and swordsmanship.

an5.135:2.2.pli: ‘ahaṃ khomhi ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca, saṃsuddhagahaṇiko, yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena.
an5.135:2.2.eng: ‘I’m well born on both my mother’s and father’s side, of pure descent, with irrefutable and impeccable genealogy back to the seventh paternal generation.

an5.135:2.3.eng: Why shouldn’t I aspire to kingship?

an5.135:2.4.pli: Ahaṃ khomhi abhirūpo dassanīyo pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato.
an5.135:2.4.eng: I’m attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty.

an5.135:2.5.eng: Why shouldn’t I aspire to kingship?

an5.135:2.6.eng: I’m dear and beloved to my parents.

an5.135:2.7.eng: Why shouldn’t I aspire to kingship?

an5.135:2.8.eng: I’m dear and beloved to the people of town and country.

an5.135:2.9.eng: Why shouldn’t I aspire to kingship?

an5.135:2.10.pli: Ahaṃ khomhi yāni tāni raññaṃ khattiyānaṃ muddhāvasittānaṃ sippaṭṭhānāni hatthismiṃ vā assasmiṃ vā rathasmiṃ vā dhanusmiṃ vā tharusmiṃ vā, tattha sikkhito anavayo.
an5.135:2.10.eng: I’m trained and skilled in the arts of anointed aristocratic kings, such as elephant riding, horse riding, driving a chariot, archery, and swordsmanship.

an5.135:2.11.eng: Why shouldn’t I aspire to kingship?’

an5.135:2.12.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi aṅgehi samannāgato rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa jeṭṭho putto rajjaṃ pattheti.
an5.135:2.12.eng: An anointed aristocratic king’s eldest son with these five factors aspires to kingship.

an5.135:3.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayaṃ pattheti.
an5.135:3.1.eng: In the same way, a mendicant with five qualities aspires to end the defilements.

an5.135:3.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saddho hoti, saddahati tathāgatassa bodhiṃ:
an5.135:3.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant has faith in the Realized One’s awakening:

an5.135:3.4.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
an5.135:3.4.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

an5.135:3.5.pli: Appābādho hoti appātaṅko, samavepākiniyā gahaṇiyā samannāgato nātisītāya nāccuṇhāya majjhimāya padhānakkhamāya;
an5.135:3.5.eng: They are rarely ill or unwell. Their stomach digests well, being neither too hot nor too cold, but just right, and fit for meditation.

an5.135:3.6.pli: asaṭho hoti amāyāvī, yathābhūtaṃ attānaṃ āvikattā satthari vā viññūsu vā sabrahmacārīsu;
an5.135:3.6.eng: They’re not devious or deceitful. They reveal themselves honestly to the Teacher or sensible spiritual companions.

an5.135:3.7.pli: āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu;
an5.135:3.7.eng: They live with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

an5.135:3.8.pli: paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā.
an5.135:3.8.eng: They’re wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

an5.135:4.2.eng: ‘I am a person of faith; I have faith in the Realized One’s awakening …

an5.135:4.3.pli: “itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā”ti.

an5.135:4.4.eng: Why shouldn’t I aspire to end the defilements?

an5.135:4.5.pli: Ahaṃ khomhi appābādho appātaṅko samavepākiniyā gahaṇiyā samannāgato nātisītāya nāccuṇhāya majjhimāya padhānakkhamāya.
an5.135:4.5.eng: I’m rarely ill or unwell. My stomach digests well, being neither too hot nor too cold, but just right, and fit for meditation.

an5.135:4.6.eng: Why shouldn’t I aspire to end the defilements?

an5.135:4.7.pli: Ahaṃ khomhi asaṭho amāyāvī yathābhūtaṃ attānaṃ āvikattā satthari vā viññūsu vā sabrahmacārīsu.
an5.135:4.7.eng: I’m not devious or deceitful. I reveal myself honestly to the Teacher or sensible spiritual companions.

an5.135:4.8.eng: Why shouldn’t I aspire to end the defilements?

an5.135:4.9.pli: Ahaṃ khomhi āraddhavīriyo viharāmi akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu.
an5.135:4.9.eng: I live with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. I’m strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

an5.135:4.10.eng: Why shouldn’t I aspire to end the defilements?

an5.135:4.11.pli: Ahaṃ khomhi paññavā udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā.
an5.135:4.11.eng: I’m wise. I have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

an5.135:4.12.eng: Why shouldn’t I aspire to end the defilements?’

an5.135:4.13.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayaṃ patthetī”ti.
an5.135:4.13.eng: A mendicant with these five qualities aspires to end the defilements.”

an5.136:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa jeṭṭho putto oparajjaṃ pattheti.
an5.136:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, an anointed aristocratic king’s eldest son with five factors aspires to become a viceroy.

an5.136:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa jeṭṭho putto ubhato sujāto hoti mātito ca pitito ca, saṃsuddhagahaṇiko, yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena;

an5.136:1.4.pli: abhirūpo hoti dassanīyo pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato;
an5.136:1.4.eng: He is attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty.

an5.136:1.5.eng: He is dear and beloved to his parents.

an5.136:1.6.eng: He is dear and beloved to the armed forces.

an5.136:1.7.pli: paṇḍito hoti viyatto medhāvī paṭibalo atītānāgatapaccuppanne atthe cintetuṃ.
an5.136:1.7.eng: He is astute, competent, and intelligent, able to think issues through as they bear upon the past, future, and present.

an5.136:2.2.pli: ‘ahaṃ khomhi ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca, saṃsuddhagahaṇiko, yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena.

an5.136:2.4.pli: Ahaṃ khomhi abhirūpo dassanīyo pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato.

an5.136:2.6.eng: dear and beloved to my parents …

an5.136:2.8.eng: dear and beloved to the armed forces …

an5.136:2.10.pli: Ahaṃ khomhi paṇḍito viyatto medhāvī paṭibalo atītānāgatapaccuppanne atthe cintetuṃ.
an5.136:2.10.eng: I’m astute, competent, and intelligent, able to think issues through as they bear upon the past, future, and present.

an5.136:2.11.eng: Why shouldn’t I aspire to become a viceroy?’

an5.136:2.12.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi aṅgehi samannāgato rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa jeṭṭho putto oparajjaṃ pattheti.
an5.136:2.12.eng: An anointed aristocratic king’s eldest son with these five factors aspires to become a viceroy.

an5.136:3.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayaṃ pattheti.
an5.136:3.1.eng: In the same way, a mendicant with five qualities aspires to end the defilements.

an5.136:3.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti …pe… samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu;
an5.136:3.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an5.136:3.4.eng: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s totally full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reciting them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

an5.136:3.5.eng: Their mind is firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

an5.136:3.6.pli: āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu;
an5.136:3.6.eng: They live with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

an5.136:3.7.pli: paññavā hoti, udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā.
an5.136:3.7.eng: They’re wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

an5.136:4.2.pli: ‘ahaṃ khomhi sīlavā, pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharāmi ācāragocarasampanno aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhāmi sikkhāpadesu.

an5.136:4.4.pli: Ahaṃ khomhi bahussuto sutadharo sutasannicayo, ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ abhivadanti, tathārūpā me dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.

an5.136:4.8.pli: Ahaṃ khomhi āraddhavīriyo viharāmi akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu.

an5.136:4.10.pli: Ahaṃ khomhi paññavā udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā.
an5.136:4.10.eng: wise. I have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

an5.136:4.11.eng: Why shouldn’t I aspire to end the defilements?’

an5.136:4.12.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayaṃ patthetī”ti.
an5.136:4.12.eng: A mendicant with these five qualities aspires to end the defilements.”

an5.137:1.1.pli: “Pañcime, bhikkhave, appaṃ rattiyā supanti, bahuṃ jagganti.
an5.137:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these five sleep little at night, staying mostly awake.

an5.137:1.3.pli: Itthī, bhikkhave, purisādhippāyā appaṃ rattiyā supati, bahuṃ jaggati.
an5.137:1.3.eng: A woman longing for a man.

an5.137:1.4.pli: Puriso, bhikkhave, itthādhippāyo appaṃ rattiyā supati, bahuṃ jaggati.
an5.137:1.4.eng: A man longing for a woman.

an5.137:1.5.pli: Coro, bhikkhave, ādānādhippāyo appaṃ rattiyā supati, bahuṃ jaggati.
an5.137:1.5.eng: A thief longing for their loot.

an5.137:1.6.pli: Rājā, bhikkhave, rājakaraṇīyesu yutto appaṃ rattiyā supati, bahuṃ jaggati.
an5.137:1.6.eng: A king busy with his duties.

an5.137:1.7.pli: Bhikkhu, bhikkhave, visaṃyogādhippāyo appaṃ rattiyā supati, bahuṃ jaggati.
an5.137:1.7.eng: A mendicant longing for freedom from the yoke.

an5.137:1.8.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca appaṃ rattiyā supanti, bahuṃ jaggantī”ti.
an5.137:1.8.eng: These five sleep little at night, staying mostly awake.”

an5.138:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato rañño nāgo bhattādako ca hoti okāsapharaṇo ca laṇḍasāraṇo ca salākaggāhī ca rañño nāgotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an5.138:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a royal bull elephant with five factors eats food, takes up space, drops dung, and takes a ticket, yet is still reckoned a royal bull elephant.

an5.138:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti rūpānaṃ, akkhamo saddānaṃ, akkhamo gandhānaṃ, akkhamo rasānaṃ, akkhamo phoṭṭhabbānaṃ.
an5.138:1.3.eng: It’s when a royal bull elephant can’t endure sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.

an5.138:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi aṅgehi samannāgato rañño nāgo bhattādako ca okāsapharaṇo ca laṇḍasāraṇo ca salākaggāhī ca, rañño nāgotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an5.138:1.4.eng: A royal bull elephant with these five factors eats food, takes up space, drops dung, and takes a ticket, yet is still reckoned a royal bull elephant.

an5.138:2.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu bhattādako ca hoti, okāsapharaṇo ca mañcapīṭhamaddano ca salākaggāhī ca, bhikkhutveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an5.138:2.1.eng: In the same way, a mendicant with five qualities eats food, takes up space, tramples beds and chairs, and takes a ticket, yet is still reckoned a mendicant.

an5.138:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhamo hoti rūpānaṃ, akkhamo saddānaṃ, akkhamo gandhānaṃ, akkhamo rasānaṃ, akkhamo phoṭṭhabbānaṃ.
an5.138:2.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant can’t endure sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.

an5.138:2.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu bhattādako ca hoti okāsapharaṇo ca mañcapīṭhamaddano ca salākaggāhī ca, bhikkhutveva saṅkhaṃ gacchatī”ti.
an5.138:2.4.eng: A mendicant with these five qualities eats food, takes up space, tramples beds and chairs, and takes a ticket, yet is still reckoned a mendicant.”

an5.139:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato rañño nāgo na rājāraho hoti na rājabhoggo, na rañño aṅgaṃtveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an5.139:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a royal bull elephant with five factors is not worthy of a king, not fit to serve a king, and is not reckoned a factor of kingship.

an5.139:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti rūpānaṃ, akkhamo saddānaṃ, akkhamo gandhānaṃ, akkhamo rasānaṃ, akkhamo phoṭṭhabbānaṃ.
an5.139:1.3.eng: It’s when a royal bull elephant can’t endure sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.

an5.139:2.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti rūpānaṃ?
an5.139:2.1.eng: And how is it that a royal bull elephant can’t endure sights?

an5.139:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo saṅgāmagato hatthikāyaṃ vā disvā assakāyaṃ vā disvā rathakāyaṃ vā disvā pattikāyaṃ vā disvā saṃsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmaṃ otarituṃ.
an5.139:2.2.eng: It’s when a royal bull elephant gone to battle falters and founders at the sight of a division of elephants, of cavalry, of chariots, or of infantry. It doesn’t stay firm, and fails to plunge into battle.

an5.139:2.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti rūpānaṃ.
an5.139:2.3.eng: That’s how a royal bull elephant can’t endure sights.

an5.139:3.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti saddānaṃ?
an5.139:3.1.eng: And how is it that a royal bull elephant can’t endure sounds?

an5.139:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo saṅgāmagato hatthisaddaṃ vā sutvā assasaddaṃ vā sutvā rathasaddaṃ vā sutvā pattisaddaṃ vā sutvā bheripaṇavasaṅkhatiṇavaninnādasaddaṃ vā sutvā saṃsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmaṃ otarituṃ.
an5.139:3.2.eng: It’s when a royal bull elephant gone to battle falters and founders at the sound of a division of elephants, of cavalry, of chariots, or of infantry, or the thunder of the drums, kettledrums, horns, and cymbals. It doesn’t stay firm, and fails to plunge into battle.

an5.139:3.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti saddānaṃ.
an5.139:3.3.eng: That’s how a royal bull elephant can’t endure sounds.

an5.139:4.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti gandhānaṃ?
an5.139:4.1.eng: And how is it that a royal bull elephant can’t endure smells?

an5.139:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo saṅgāmagato ye te rañño nāgā abhijātā saṅgāmāvacarā tesaṃ muttakarīsassa gandhaṃ ghāyitvā saṃsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmaṃ otarituṃ.
an5.139:4.2.eng: It’s when a royal bull elephant gone to battle falters and founders when it smells the odor of the feces and urine of battle-hardened, pedigree royal bull elephants. It doesn’t stay firm, and fails to plunge into battle.

an5.139:4.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti gandhānaṃ.
an5.139:4.3.eng: That’s how a royal bull elephant can’t endure smells.

an5.139:5.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti rasānaṃ?
an5.139:5.1.eng: And how is it that a royal bull elephant can’t endure tastes?

an5.139:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo saṅgāmagato ekissā vā tiṇodakadattiyā vimānito dvīhi vā tīhi vā catūhi vā pañcahi vā tiṇodakadattīhi vimānito saṃsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmaṃ otarituṃ.
an5.139:5.2.eng: It’s when a royal bull elephant gone to battle falters and founders when it misses a meal of grass and water, or it misses two, three, four, or five meals. It doesn’t stay firm, and fails to plunge into battle.

an5.139:5.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti rasānaṃ.
an5.139:5.3.eng: That’s how a royal bull elephant can’t endure tastes.

an5.139:6.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti phoṭṭhabbānaṃ?
an5.139:6.1.eng: And how is it that a royal bull elephant can’t endure touches?

an5.139:6.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo saṅgāmagato ekena vā saravegena viddho, dvīhi vā tīhi vā catūhi vā pañcahi vā saravegehi viddho saṃsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmaṃ otarituṃ.
an5.139:6.2.eng: It’s when a royal bull elephant gone to battle falters and founders when struck by a swift arrow, or by two, three, four, or five swift arrows. It doesn’t stay firm, and fails to plunge into battle.

an5.139:6.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti phoṭṭhabbānaṃ.
an5.139:6.3.eng: That’s how a royal bull elephant can’t endure touches.

an5.139:7.1.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi aṅgehi samannāgato rañño nāgo na rājāraho hoti na rājabhoggo na rañño aṅgaṃtveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an5.139:7.1.eng: A royal bull elephant with these five factors is not worthy of a king, not fit to serve a king, and is not reckoned a factor of kingship.

an5.139:8.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi aṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu na āhuneyyo hoti na pāhuneyyo na dakkhiṇeyyo na añjalikaraṇīyo na anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an5.139:8.1.eng: In the same way, a mendicant with five qualities is not worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, not worthy of hospitality, not worthy of a religious donation, not worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is not the supreme field of merit for the world.

an5.139:8.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhamo hoti rūpānaṃ, akkhamo saddānaṃ, akkhamo gandhānaṃ, akkhamo rasānaṃ, akkhamo phoṭṭhabbānaṃ.
an5.139:8.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant can’t endure sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.

an5.139:9.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhamo hoti rūpānaṃ?
an5.139:9.1.eng: And how is it that a mendicant can’t endure sights?

an5.139:9.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā rajanīye rūpe sārajjati, na sakkoti cittaṃ samādahituṃ.
an5.139:9.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, seeing a sight with their eyes, is aroused by a desirable sight, so is not able to still the mind.

an5.139:9.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhamo hoti rūpānaṃ.
an5.139:9.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant can’t endure sights.

an5.139:10.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhamo hoti saddānaṃ?
an5.139:10.1.eng: And how is it that a mendicant can’t endure sounds?

an5.139:10.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sotena saddaṃ sutvā rajanīye sadde sārajjati, na sakkoti cittaṃ samādahituṃ.
an5.139:10.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, hearing a sound with their ears, is aroused by a desirable sound, so is not able to still the mind.

an5.139:10.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhamo hoti saddānaṃ.
an5.139:10.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant can’t endure sounds.

an5.139:11.1.eng: And how is it that a mendicant can’t endure smells?

an5.139:11.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ghānena gandhaṃ ghāyitvā rajanīye gandhe sārajjati, na sakkoti cittaṃ samādahituṃ.
an5.139:11.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, smelling an odor with their nose, is aroused by a desirable smell, so is not able to still the mind.

an5.139:11.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhamo hoti gandhānaṃ.
an5.139:11.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant can’t endure smells.

an5.139:12.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhamo hoti rasānaṃ?
an5.139:12.1.eng: And how is it that a mendicant can’t endure tastes?

an5.139:12.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu jivhāya rasaṃ sāyitvā rajanīye rase sārajjati, na sakkoti cittaṃ samādahituṃ.
an5.139:12.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, tasting a flavor with their tongue, is aroused by desirable tastes, so is not able to still the mind.

an5.139:12.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhamo hoti rasānaṃ.
an5.139:12.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant can’t endure tastes.

an5.139:13.1.eng: And how is it that a mendicant can’t endure touches?
